references: In Fig. 2, the cost function using norm 222 (L2) and norm 111 (L1) versus iterations is depicted for different values of Îµnsubscriptğœ€ğ‘›\varepsilon_{n} and Î´ğ›¿\delta in the training phase. As a base line, we compare the result of FL with its centralized counterpart solution (black curve in Fig. 2). Since the iteration numbers of the federated learning and its centralized solution are not comparable, we plot the final solution for the centralized counterpart problem. The results in Fig. 2 highlight that Lâ€‹2ğ¿2L2 with Îµ=0.1ğœ€0.1\varepsilon=0.1 outperforms the other parameter setup for this data set. The interesting point is that for all Lâ€‹2ğ¿2L2 and Lâ€‹1ğ¿1L1 with different Îµ=0.2ğœ€0.2\varepsilon=0.2, the converged results of federated learning with this protection function is almost better than that of centralized counterpart. In Table 2, we show the accuracy of the training set versus Îµğœ€\varepsilon for Lâ€‹2ğ¿2L2 and Lâ€‹1ğ¿1L1 norms in protection function in different iteration number. From this results it is clear that Lâ€‹2ğ¿2L2 with Îµ=0.1ğœ€0.1\varepsilon=0.1 has a fast convergence rate, i.e., its accuracy in 404040 iteration is above 80%. All other experiments with different protection functions almost approaches 85/% or more after 120120120 iterations. Note that the accuracy of the centralized solution counterpart of our experiment is around 50%percent5050\%. This results supports our discussions after Remark 1 that using the federated learning with different regularization factors allow to search the all non-convex feasible set of problem (1) and there is a chance to converge to a better solution compared to the centralized counterpart problem. Also, there is not any linear relation between increasing the uncertainty bound and decreasing or increasing the cost. This results are valid for this data set and for other data sets, the experiment should be run and the best value of pğ‘p and Îµnsubscriptğœ€ğ‘›\varepsilon_{n} should be determined.
